abstracts.cdata!:
The Inland Waterways and Port
            Modernization Project in Vietnam consists of improvements to
            sections of two main waterways south of Ho Chi Minh City and
            within the Mekong River Delta, thus providing for increased
            vessel haulage capacity. Improvements to Can Tho Port will
            provide for better cargo handling, cargo storage, and
            treatment/disposal of ship wastes. This environmental
            assessment evaluates adverse biophysical impacts related to
            project activities both during construction and operation
            phases; presents mitigation measures to reduce both
            predicted and actual impacts; and reports on the
            environmental aspects of the project, including temporary
            and permanent adverse impacts and benefits. During
            construction of the waterway and the Thoi Binh Lock, various
            mitigation measures will be adopted to reduce impacts
            identified as unacceptable, that is, a more than 20 percent
            change in oxygen levels and pH concentrations in the
            waterway; a more than 20 percent change in other critical
            elements (totally suspended liquids, oil or fecal
            coliform-bacteria, and the 5 trace metals) in potable water;
            or a decrease of 2 pH units beyond the normal range in
            aquaculture. Measures include: altering dredging activities
            to reduce release of suspended solids and associated
            contaminants by either reducing dredging intensity; or
            changing dredging operational practices. Dredging of the
            bank of some waterway sections may change the pH of water in
            the channels - this must be considered a residual
            non-mitigable impact. If unacceptable changes also occur in
            the pH of potable water and in water used in aquaculture,
            other options are to modify dredging operational practices,
            to increase monitoring, and to re-evaluate physical soil
            conditions. Actions to mitigate unacceptable changes in the
            normal range of concentrations in dissolved oxygen, total
            suspended liquids, fecal coliform bacteria, or a decrease
            below the normal range of pH concentration will prompt a
            reduction in the rate of water discharge from any or all of
            the water basins. Persistent or abrupt noise exceeding a set
            decibel level will be mitigated by installing additional
            noise dampening on the dredge or the booster pumping
            stations; altering the timing of certain work practices; or
            penalizing the contractor and transferring these funds to
            the community as compensation. The operational phase of the
            waterways and the Thoi Binh Lock will cause increased
            erosion and the collapse of canal banks, with stronger tidal
            effects leading to greater seawater intrusion, significantly
            impacting aquatic and terrestrial ecology (food source loss,
            and destroyed habitats, aquatic plants, and animal species)
            and agriculture, lessening the ability to use canal water
            for other uses, promoting sedimentation, and increasing
            salinity. Canal dredging will increase fresh water from
            upstream, and discharge and acidic and salt water will be
            pushed further downstream, particularly in the wet season.
            Increased vessel traffic will lead to: 1) uncontrolled
            discharge, which will increase existing waste impacts to the
            general aquatic ecosystem of the canals and rivers, coastal
            marine ecosystem and human health of waterway users; and 2)
            increased potential for spillage of petroleum hydrocarbon
            products, such as fuels, hydraulic line oils, etc. Noise
            will be mitigated by controls, such as banning whistles and
            horns or fining vessels with inadequate muffler systems. The
            operational phase of the Can Tho Port will increase noise,
            which will be mitigated by installing upgraded mufflers on
            cranes and vehicles. The port will be required to provide
            facilities to receive and treat oil-contaminated waters,
            chemical-contaminated waters, sanitary sewage, and
            shipwaste. Stormwater drainage will transport surface runoff
            of pollutants into the Bassac River. A resettlement action
            plan conforming to the World Bank's operational
            directive is included.
